Award.AwardTitle: Student Support: 2018 Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference and 46th North American Manufacturing Research Conference; College Station, Texas; June 18-22, 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports 78 graduate and undergraduate students studying at US institutions to participate in the co-located conference event consisting of the 2018 International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference sponsored by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the 46th Annual North American Manufacturing Research Conference sponsored by the North American Manufacturing Research Institution of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers. These two leading conferences in the Manufacturing Engineering field act as global bridges between industries, government laboratories, and academic institutions. The award provides student participants with opportunities to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from worldwide industrial and governmental facilities, as well as with students and faculty from both domestic and international schools. In addition to nurturing a global manufacturing vision, participants will learn the latest research areas and results in manufacturing fields.

Submitted applications go through a selection process by the conference committee. Eligibility criteria to receive the support are described in the proposal, but the approach prioritizes underrepresented groups and students that are actively engaged in the conference through papers or posters. The grant administrators will make an effort to recruit underrepresented minorities and women students and to obtain a balanced representation from many universities. The support will cover (1) the registration fees, and (2) the accommodation cost in a shared room for the entire duration of the conference. The call for student support applications is disseminated through posting on main conference websites; promulgation through conference organizers, track chairs, and symposium organizers; and direct communication with students involved in poster session, student design competition, and student author research presentation competition. The submitted applications go through a selection process by the conference committee. The eligibility criteria to receive the funding include (1) students must be from US institutions, and (2) students must be actively participating in the conference through presenting a paper or poster, or participating in a competition. The two highest selection ranks are given to students who have multiple technical papers accepted and students who present technical papers resulting from research supported by NSF. After the conference, the list of student awardees will be announced on the main conference website, in the Manufacturing Science and Engineering 2017 post-conference report in the Manufacturing Engineering Division's Newsletter, and in the Award and Recognition section on the North American Manufacturing Research Institution's website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant helped 78 full-time engineering students from 53 different U.S. universities and colleges defray the cost to attend the co-located 2018 ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC2018) and the NAMRI/SME 46thNorth American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC46) held at Texas A&M University on June 18 – June 22, 2018. 127 unique applications were received from 54 U.S. universities and colleges. The 78 awardees included 64 Ph.D. students, five M.S. students, nine B.S. students, 16 women, eight students from historically under-represented groups, two veterans, and one student who identified as having a disability. Most of these students presented their original manufacturing research or project at the conference. The grant paid for the conference registration fee and lodging for students who were selected for the award. 

MSEC 2018 was sponsored by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and NAMRC 46 was sponsored by the North American Manufacturing Research Institution of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers (NAMRI/SME). These are each world-class conferences in the Manufacturing Engineering field, and as such act as global bridges between industries, government laboratories, and academic institutions.  

The grant, which enabled to students to participate in this international manufacturing research conference, allowed these students to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from industrial and governmental facilities around the world, as well as with students and faculty from both domestic and international universities.  Participation in this conference nurtured the students’ global manufacturing vision, and let them learn about the latest research and developments in manufacturing engineering. These opportunities not only improved the participants’ knowledge of manufacturing technologies but also help them develop into engineers and researchers that are ideally suited to lead the next generation of U.S. manufacturing. 

Intellectual Merit:  The grant enabled 78 engineering students from U.S. universities and colleges to participate in a conference with over 350 technical papers and 40 posters on advanced manufacturing research. The four-day conference, an international forum focusing on manufacturing, brought together over 700 participants that these students had the opportunity to learn from and network with. At the co-organized MSEC/NAMRC conference the students learned about the latest trends in all aspects of advanced manufacturing. This four-day conference was an international forum focusing on manufacturing, which is key to the U.S. economy. The single registration fee allowed students to attend all the technical events and receive the conference proceedings. 

Broader Impacts:  The grant enabled 78 students from U.S. universities and colleges to participate in the preeminent manufacturing research gathering in the United States. Participation not only stimulated learning and training for the participants, but also allowed them to see new manufacturing research concepts and interact with the researchers defining them.Their participation helped them acquire a broader understanding of advanced manufacturing technology, become involved with professional societies, and motivate their intellectual curiosity through the development of a professional network. This contact network will continue to support the students in the long term, through their professional career. Overall, this grant strengthened the advanced manufacturing workforce pipeline for the manufacturing field in the United States.
